content: The Maldives consists of numerous low-lying and scattered islands
- Islam introduced.
- Portuguese occupation, which ends after expulsion by locals.
- Islands become a protectorate first of the Dutch rulers of Ceylon (Sri Lanka) and later of the British who take control of Ceylon in 1796.
- Status formalised as internally self-governing British protectorate.
- First democratic constitution proclaimed. The sultanate becomes an elected position.
- Becomes a republic within the Commonwealth as the sultanate is abolished. However, the Sultan is restored within months.
The Maldive islands are a favourite destination for sunseeking tourists
- Full independence as a sultanate outside Commonwealth.
- Sultan deposed after referendum; republic reinstated with Ibrahim Nasir as president.
- Nasir retires, replaced by Maumoon Abdul Gayoom.
- Development of tourist industry fuels economic growth.
- Rejoins Commonwealth.
- Coup attempt involving Sri Lankan mercenaries foiled with the help of Indian commandos.
November - Parliamentary elections take place, with more than 120 independent candidates contesting 40 seats.
Some islands were badly hit by the tsunami in 2004
September - President Gayoom warns low-lying islands at greater risk than ever before, and calls on international community to take urgent action to prevent global environmental catastrophe.
September - Unprecedented anti-government riots break out in Male, sparked by deaths of four prison inmates.
October - Mr Gayoom re-elected for unprecedented sixth term in presidential referendum, winning more than 90% of the vote.
June - President Gayoom promises constitutional changes to limit presidential term and allow formation of political parties.
August - State of emergency imposed after a pro-democracy demonstration turns violent. Almost 100 people are jailed.
Elections in 2008 ended the 30-year rule of President Gayoom

December - Scores of people are killed and many islands suffer severe damage when a tsunami generated by a powerful undersea earthquake off the Indonesian coast hits the Maldives. The government says the disaster set development work back by 20 years.
June - Parliament votes unanimously to allow multi-party politics.
August - Opposition party leader Mohamed Nasheed is charged with terrorism and sedition.
March - President Gayoom unveils a "roadmap" for democratic reforms, which he says will enhance multi-party politics.

August - President Gayoom pardons senior opposition figure Jennifer Latheef, who was serving a 10-year term on terrorism charges, but she refuses to recognise the pardon and demands a retrial to clear her name.
August - Voters in a referendum back President Gayoom's proposal for a presidential system of government.
January - President Gayoom survives an assassination attempt after 15-year-old boy scout Mohamed Jaisham wrestled a kitchen knife from the would-be killer's hands.
August - President Gayoom ratifies new constitution that paves the way for first multi-party presidential elections.
October - Opposition leader Mohamed Nasheed defeats President Gayoom in second round of voting, inaugurated as president in November.
March - President Nasheed says the Maldives will become carbon-neutral within a decade by switching completely to renewable energy sources.
April - President Nasheed says government will deregulate the state-controlled media and ensure media freedom and competition.
May - Police clash with opposition-led protesters complaining about food prices.
Demonstrators protest against rising food prices in May 2011
January - Row erupts over arrest of the chief justice, who ordered the release of a government critic.
February - President Nasheed announces his resignation after a mutiny by the police and weeks of demonstrations over the arrest of the chief justice. Later, he says he was forced out in a coup.
Vice-president Mohamed Waheed Hussain Manik is sworn in as president.
July - Former President Nasheed is charged with illegally ordering the arrest of the chief justice, as Nasheed supporters demonstrate and demand early elections.
August - Commonwealth-backed investigation dismisses claims that coup forced Mohamed Nasheed to step down in February. The report says Mr Nasheed resigned voluntarily.
October - Supreme Court annuls the result of the first round of presidential elections held in September because of alleged irregularities.
November - Abdulla Yameen, half-brother of former President Gayoom, wins presidential election run-off.

March - The Maldives Supreme Court gives all four election commissioners six-month suspended jail sentences for "disobeying orders". In October 2013 the head of the commission criticised the Supreme Court after it annulled presidential election deemed free and fair by observers.

March - Former president Mohammed Nasheed is jailed for 13 years after being found guilty on terrorism charges. The verdict, which his party says is politically motivated. elicits international concern from governments and rights groups.

- November - Government declares state of emergency for 30 days ahead of mass rally in support of jailed former president Nasheed, allowing security forces to detain suspects without charge, and shutting down major online news sites.
- November - Government lifts state of emergency following mounting international pressure.
February - Sheikh Imran Abdulla, the leader of the Islamist opposition Adhaalath Party, is jailed for 12 years on a terrorism charge for inciting unrest during an anti-government rally.
Former President Mohamed Nasheed was granted refugee status in the United Kingdom in 2016
May - Former president Mohamed Nasheed is granted refugee status in Britain.
June - Former vice-president Ahmed Adeeb is convicted of plotting to assassinate President Abdulla Yameen and jailed for 15 years.
August - Parliament passes new defamation bill despite US-led international concern that it risks undermining basic freedoms.

October - The Maldives announces it is leaving the Commonwealth. The international organisation had earlier warned the country that it risked suspension if it failed to show progress in promoting democracy.
February - Political turmoil as government defies Supreme Court order to free prisoners whose convictions it had quashed.
September - Opposition leader Ibrahim Mohamed Solih scores surprise win over President Abdulla Yameen in presidential election.
